awd_abstract_narration:
Project Growing Pathways to Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (Project GPS) will provide scholarships for 25 academically talented, low-income students pursuing Associate of Science degrees in STEM fields. The project will focus on rural students in the State of Nebraska, and will work with local high schools that offer both dual credit and career pathways, to assist in early identification and recruitment of academically talented scholars. Students will benefit from mentorship through networking, team-building, and practical career experience, that includes unique, collaborative college-industry partnerships. Support services will address financial and academic support barriers specific to rural student success. 

Project GPS will investigate an interventionist model of the relationships between mentors, cohorts, students, and industry. This potentially transformative model is possible through college-industry-community partnerships. These partnerships will bridge established gaps that inhibit student success, and help students develop critical thinking skills needed for life beyond the community college. An Immersive Service Learning Experience (ISLE) will provide an intensive orientation experience and include a summer component with student participation in independent/collaborative research, a cooperative education program, or industry internship/job shadow experiences influenced by cohort composition and local business/industry input. All ISLE projects will incorporate global sustainability concepts on a local scale, with intended measurable benefits in and beyond the local community. The project will generate new knowledge regarding the engagement and support of rural, community college students, and effective practices for supporting their degree completion and transfer to baccalaureate degree programs or entry into the STEM workforce.

por.por_cntn:
The Growing Pathways to STEM (GPS) project goal was to increase students entering the STEM workforce or advanced education.  Project GPS sought to help Central Community College (CCC) better serve academically talented students with a demonstrated financial need by removing barriers to their success and offering systematic supports to increase the likelihood of GPS Scholars pursuing postsecondary STEM education, completing an advanced STEM degree, overcoming identified attrition points, and successfully being employed in a STEM career.

The project provided enhanced learning and networking activities to encourage student retention and completion of STEM-focused education through focused curriculum, an immersive service-learning experience, a cohort experience, professional mentoring, and career development activities.  The project also deeply involved students in hands-on research experiences that contributed to their STEM knowledge, interests, skills, and sense of community belonging.  Many of these experiences were cutting edge research investigations with avian, bee, and fungi contexts, and using many different approaches that were co-developed by the students and faculty, such as for example investigating local bird mutations, creating fungi bee hotels for bee research, and fungi products such as a functional canoe within the context of material development and engineering applications.  Students also published research posters, abstracts, and papers, and routinely presented at local, state, national and even international professional conferences.

There were many successes of the GPS project, including supporting a total of 44 different students, who were given scholarships, and another 8 or 9 have participated in some activities as Friends of GPS while not receiving a scholarship. As the grant target was 25 students, the project exceeded that initial target by more than 75%.  Additionally, the project helped STEM students to get Research Experiences for Undergraduate (REU) experience and to be involved in many other college and university level support mechanisms within Nebraska.

Over the duration of the NSF grant, the project also had an impressive 90% student retention rate, a 65% transfer rate to university programs, and a 25% rate of those leaving the program to enter STEM fields directly. The grant awarded over $380,000 in direct scholarships to students.  Further, the project assisted in helping Central Community College be recognized by donors for their tremendous potential for supporting and inspiring STEM students, with private donations that allowed the building of new laboratory facilities inspired by the GPS student research efforts and resulting in a truly model facility that now represents some of the highest quality laboratory and instructional facilities in community colleges today.

Finally, Project GPS established, in many ways, a national model of how community college students could not only learn STEM concepts by doing hands-on research, but also, that they could contribute to a given body of research in a field as well, drawing upon their own fresh perspectives, and the inspirations of their faculty mentors and their many community partners.


Last Modified: 06/30/2023
Modified by: Steven Heinisch
